The Shawshank Redemption is widely regarded as one of the greatest movies ever made, and it's easy to see why. Directed by Frank Darabont and based on a novella by Stephen King, the film is a powerful meditation on hope, redemption, and the resilience of the human spirit.

The movie tells the story of Andy Dufresne, played by Tim Robbins, a man who is wrongfully convicted of murder and sent to Shawshank State Penitentiary. In prison, Andy forms a friendship with fellow inmate Red, played by Morgan Freeman, and sets about using his intelligence and resourcefulness to survive and even thrive in the brutal and oppressive environment of the prison.

One of the strengths of The Shawshank Redemption is its nuanced portrayal of the characters. Andy and Red are complex and multifaceted individuals, and their friendship is depicted with a depth and authenticity that is rare in Hollywood films. The movie also features a talented supporting cast, including Bob Gunton as the sadistic Warden Norton and William Sadler as the troubled and tragic Heywood.

But perhaps the greatest strength of The Shawshank Redemption is its message of hope and redemption. Even in the darkest and most hopeless of circumstances, the movie suggests, there is always the possibility of redemption and the potential for a better future. Andy's determination to survive and maintain his humanity in the face of incredible adversity is inspiring and uplifting, and the film's ultimate message of hope and renewal is both moving and profound.

Visually, The Shawshank Redemption is also a masterpiece. The film's cinematography and production design are both striking and memorable, and the use of music, particularly the haunting and beautiful score by Thomas Newman, adds to the movie's emotional impact.

Overall, The Shawshank Redemption is a powerful and deeply moving film that resonates with audiences on a profound level. Its themes of hope and redemption are universal, and its message of the transformative power of human connection and resilience is one that will continue to inspire and uplift viewers for years to come.

The movies that were called the dark horse of the industry were unexpected and impressive movies that will stick in your mind for a long time. A drama film called Shawshank Redemption is the story of a banker, Andy Dufresne, who was caught up in the murder of his wife and her adultery then. Their story is about the rest of his life in the Shawshank prison, the friendship, and the pain of reality. One of the most interesting parts of this movie is that it is told from a third-person point of view, which gives a new perspective by using an indirect approach. It depicts a lot of inequity in prison life, but the focus point in this movie is hope. The hope that could rarely be found in a place that was called "hopeless," such as prison, is the reason why the movie wants to show freedom in ways that people could never have imagined that people in prison would still have hope. This is not the normal prison film that audiences expect about jailbreak, but this movie leads to a different feeling. It's gained emotion through the situation that the characters have been through, and even more emotion is gained by the impressive ending. The movie always showed you some phases that demonstrated the truth of being human; that will definitely hit you. You will be able to relate a scenario, a character, or a situation in this simple movie to something deeply personal in your own life after experiencing it. This kind of movie is great to keep watching more than once because your thoughts and perspective on it will change as you grow up.
Shawshank Redemption could of course be called an encouraging film, and that is also the aim of the director, but in my understanding, this film is bittersweet and more bitter than sweet. Because the character's pain is shown a lot in this film, the key is how he deals with the situation and how it would be if there were a condition in the situation. But what is beautiful is the strong relationships that exist in this place, and you will feel that while watching it. Along with great performances from actors like Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins, it was one of the best. But there are also live support acts that are absolutely brilliant and impressive. Although most of the scenes of the film take place in a tense place. 
I would recommend this movie for the two and a half hours that it is worth for people who want to experience a simple but golden movie story like The Shawshank Redemption. You will even more clearly understand why this movie is the highest rated on IMDB. However, I recommended this movie to older teenage audiences because some of the content in the movie is violent, and the context of that content will become clearer to this generation or older. Finally, The Shawshank Redemption offers you a variety of experiences that will definitely give you brilliant pleasure.

The Shawshank Redemption follows a group of prison inmates as they serve out their sentences.

This film is nothing short of phenomenal and I can see why it is considered among many as the greatest film ever created. My favourite two kinds of films consist of crowd pleasers and deep dive dramas that focus on certain lifestyles. This film fills both those slots. We get to see how exactly prison affects people and everything that is involved with being a prisoner. We also get some great moments towards the end that put a smile on your face every time you watch it.

Across the board incredible acting, Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman both give probably their greatest performance, along side the rest of this perfect cast.

Tim Robbins character Andy Dufresne gives us the angle of an innocent man entering prison, but not just an innocent man an intelligent innocent and I'll get to why his intelligence is so important later. We get to see Andy go through different stages of prison as we see what happens to people that are alone in prison, how they get targeted out by rapists and how they are treated with zero respect. Then we get to see what happens when you have something to offer the guards and the warden, in Andy's case it's is knowledge of banking. We see Andy begin by helping guards set up savings accounts and help them with their taxes all of which help him get in good with guards. But eventually we get to see how certain guards or in this case the warden may be worse then the people imprisoned. Warden Norton played by Bob Gunton recruits Andy to help him launder money, but once Andy has a chance at getting out the Warden makes sure he can't leave by killing the person that could lead Andy to freedom. This again gives us a great angle into what goes on in these prisons and how guards and wardens take advantage of their authority since they know inmates can do nothing to stop them. 

We don't find out until the end of the film but throughout his time in prison Andy has been digging a hole to escape, which really adds another layer onto why he does the things he does. Andy has been attempting to make the lives of these inmates better so when he eventually escapes he doesn't feel guilty for leaving his friends in a unsafe environment. We see him build up a large library as well as teach certain inmates so they can receive their high school diploma. Then at the end Andy is responsible for the arrest and ‘almost arrest' of the warden and captain hadley.

Another side of prison we get to see are the prisoners who have essentially spent their lives in prison. Red played by Morgan Freeman has become somewhat of a tycoon in prison, as he is one of the people that smuggle into the prison. By the time Red is released he had spent 40 years in prison and isn't accustomed to life outside, so when he is released and begins working he realizes that he is not meant to be outside of prison. 

Another character in this film had the same revelation. Brooks Hatlen played by James Whitmore was released from prison earlier in the film but when he had that revelation he committed suicide. Red on the other hand was lucky enough to have a friend like Andy. Before Andy escaped we get to see him give instructions to Red on where to find a rock, and under that rock is where Andy had hidden something. Under that rock was a letter to Red explaining where Andy was and that he would love to have his help with a new project of his. That is when we get to see the two reunite in a very satisfying conclusion.

Thoughts upon watching this film in 2022:
It has the aura of a fairy tale. The prisoners, hard core as they may be, are like mythical creatures: Morgan Freeman as the kindly convict, James Whitmore as the tragic librarian, and Tim Robbins as the soft spoken but conniving Andy. None of them are realistic. They're romanticized. But we're captivated by them thanks to a great screenplay and strong performances.
It's a man's movie. This was obvious the first time I watched it. I thought women might have a hard time relating to it. But after my recent viewing, I realized that a great story transcends gender issues and has universal appeal.
William Sadler, in an early role, gives a strong supporting performance.
Roger Deakins is, without doubt one of the finest cinematographers in the history of film. His camera work in this movie alone could be an entire class in film school.
There are so many improbable scenes, like the beer drinking scene on the roof and the scene in which Andy broadcasts an opera record over the prison P.A. It's sheer romanticism—and we eat it up.
Clearly, Andy is a Christ-like figure. It's a story that never fails. His "death" is his sentence and the beatings he takes in prison. His "resurrection" is his prison break. He does good for his brethren, but he has no mercy on the warden. The corrupt and hypocritical warden represents the money changers in the temple, and Andy, in righteous anger,  overturns his table. 
The denouement of the film ties in nicely with an earlier mention by Andy of Robert Frost. The poem in question is "Mending Wall." Those who have read it will understand.
Lastly, I've never understood why this film, now regarded as a masterpiece,  was a box office failure. What were people thinking in 1994? Or maybe they weren't thinking.

Shawshank Redemption is without doubt one of the best films ever made, and definitely the best film of 1994. Yes, it is better than Lion King, and I really like that too. It is not only enthralling but powerful and moving too. I will confess that I didn't understand it when I first saw it as a lot happens in the film, and I have now seen it three times. I seriously hope, that those who ignored the film when it was first released now recognise it as a great film, as it really is. The dialogue was extremely well-written, with lines that really stick in your mind. The cinematography and music are both gorgeous, and the prison itself is like a character that dominates the film. In the script, there are some true elements of Stephen King Now I admit I am not a huge king fan, and usually don't like coarse language in books. But in his books like It, which is very good, I have accepted the language represents brutality and rebellion, shown perfectly in the film with the battle of acceptance I suppose between the inmates and the superiors(like the scene with the warden yelling coarse language at the new inmates lined up in a row at the beginning.)The acting was exceptional. I am not hugely familiar with Tim Robbins, but he did a great job in a very demanding role. The best performance however, comes from Morgan Freeman as Red, who was seriously robbed of that Oscar, that he lost to Tom Hanks for Forrest Gump. Freeman reminds me very strongly, or his style of acting does, remind me of that of Sean Connery, suave yet very charismatic. Acting isn't just about your vocal range, it's about depth, which was what Freeman certainly had. In short, Freeman was brilliant in what could be his best performance. The scene where the inmates are listening to the Mozart aria over the speakers was a beautiful profound moment, and I actually cried in Brook's death scene. Very rarely do King adaptations translate-to screen well, because of the large scale of the author's books, with the exception of this and the Shining. Some like It and Dreamcatcher are genuinely memorable but have a number of flaws that prevent them from being classed as outstanding. And some, like Thinner and Tommyknockers that border on unwatchable. In conclusion Shawshank is a brilliant film, that is worthy of the credit it has been denied for so-long. 10/10 of course. "The Shawshank Redemption" is a cinematic masterpiece BEYOND dispute! It's first-rate cast enlivens Darabont's tremendously well-written script based upon the acclaimed novel by eminent novelist, Stephen King. I was amazed at how easy it was to sympathize with some of the film's convicts. The characters served as true to life exemplars of the effects of the cruelty of institutionalism. The theme of one's mindset and ability to hope determining their freedom gives the story THAT much more significance and merit. To have any kind of hope in a predicament as hopeless as serving a back-to-back life sentence is exceptional and well worth figuring out what the hell the two hours and twenty-two minute runtime is all about.

Oddly enough, the film does not display itself as bulky as it's runtime suggests. The film takes place over the course of several decades, only focusing BRIEFLY on any period of time. The clever editing and marvelous directing maintained the picture's steady pace. We're able to focus on and be more intrigued with the development of the two leads rather than how long they've been imprisoned. I was interested with how some characters were able to change their actions, while still transitioning between a mindset that is not so healthy to a mindset that would lead them to a better, freer life. It's immensely realistic and I'm certain that other viewers could see some of their selves in the characters made infamous by the phenomenal actors involved.

For a long, long time I wondered what was really going on. 9.3 out of 10 possible points on the world's largest film database IMDb, even before classics like The Godfather Part 1 and 2 and leader of some best lists. Yet it's just about a convicted banker who befriends Morgan Freeman and gets used to his life as a prisoner in Shawshank men's prison. But there's a lot more to this film than the blue-eyed setting up of modern movie clichés.

For the crux of The Shawshank Redemption already lies in its ensemble. Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman as the leading men in their absolute prime as actors. Secondary characters that integrate ideally into the scenarios of the protagonists and all have essential functions as their companions. Villains that seem generic from today's point of view, but for those times were unparalleled in cruelty. All of these ingeniously written roles have a hand in the plot, none of them feeling superfluous at any point. Of course, the film's trump card is the chemistry between Robbin's character Andy and Freeman's Red. After an initial distance, the two grow closer and closer as the film progresses, and within the nearly 30 years over which the plot takes place, they become almost inseparable. A down-to-earth and simple male friendship, where both of them share a terrible fate. How the two manage to carry each other through the cold harshness of prison life is gripping to follow. The individual scenes mainly belong to Robbin's Andy. This one is characterized by Red's over-voice and while this movie tool works in very few cases, it's a bull's eye here. It's not for nothing that Freeman's voice is considered iconic to this day. You have from the start that a man is telling his friend's story. Freeman's screen time suffers a bit as a result, but it doesn't take anything away from what is arguably the best performance of his career. Robbins delivers the much quieter and subtler performance, while Freeman excels in empathetic and even comedic monologues and dialogue at times. The rest of the cast adds to an all-around perfect ensemble performance. Foremost among them is Bob Gunton as the corrupt Warden Norton, under whose hypocritical posturing as a sensible Christian lurks a malicious layer that lends the film some (necessary) devastation.

Whether The Shawshank Redemption is really the best film of all time is debatable. However, one thing can't be denied: From an objective point of view, it is without major weaknesses. If anything, the slightly pathetic and conventional ending actually fits seamlessly with the previous plot. In this respect, this is perhaps a point of criticism, but merely one without much significance. Otherwise, it's a film that still did a lot to me at 22 years old, even 27 years later. The sensations of pain, shock and happiness regularly catch up with you. Despite its epic running length and slow build, the film is always entertaining and engaging, and it's also beautifully directed and photographed. Hard to find any flaws here.

It's quite seldom that one comes across a film-or any form of art, with such a sublime marriage of bleak and beauty, harmony and distortion, pain and salvation-as the film named ‘The Shawshank Redemption'. Directed by Frank Darabont, in 1994-this masterpiece of a movie, revolved around two inmates-Andy Dufresne (Potrayed by Tim Robbins) and Red (Morgan Freeman) and the close bond the two shared. The film is narrated by Red as he reflects on the various trials and tribulations Andy had to go through, whilst at the prison-named Shawshank. A minor detail but the deep baritone of Morgan Freeman's voice, never fails to seduce the viewer's attention and interest. However, no movie or rather-no good movie, is complete without a good soundtrack; This is where Shawshank Redemption's music composer-Thomas Newman, flexes his musical expertise. The soundtrack in the movie is almost akin to a tender dance between two ballerinas-one portraying hope and the other, portraying the melancholy that Andy feels. Apart from this, Frank Darabont's creative decision of playing Italian opera music at a notable scene in the movie-and conveying, without words; the emotions and mindset of every single prisoner at one go. Before we talk about the story-the cinematography has to be applauded. The minor changes in the lighting that usually go unnoticed-but which subconsciously lend to the very atmosphere of the scene is present in spades. Besides, the gross change in atmosphere during a happy scene or a bleak proverbial fog-covering the sad ones, can be found throughout the movie. The story is one tinged with hope, sadness and sheer desperation. Hope for freedom and a bright future, outside the walls of the prison. Sadness at the sight of the heavily armed guards and inescapable layout of the prison, preventing the dream from becoming reality-and sheer desperation to achieve it. The viewer is entangled in a web of emotions as they sink further and further into the movie until, pausing the movie and going about their daily lives becomes a distant thought, nay, a taboo. It is impossible to describe the movie in detail without delving into spoilers-but one has to experience it, instead of reading the words of another. True praise has to be given to the actors Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman. Their acting was so sublime and so well performed that at one point, one had difficulty believing that they were actors and not real inmates. The level of dedication and commitment the actors had put in, was off the charts and some of the behind-the-scenes and facts about the film, further certify it. To end, one would have to say that The Shawshank Redemption is one of those movies that will put a curse on you-that of not being able to forget it or even stop thinking about it, long after the credits have stopped rolling. This film is not a masterpiece, but a sublime show of magic that will continue to trap audiences, throughout the ages.

This movie will most likely make your all time greatest list. It's one of those movies that if you happen to notice it's on TV, you'll most likely watch the rest of movie because it's that good. It's also one of those movies that makes you wish you could watch it all over again for the first time. If you haven't seen it yet you're in for a real treat.
What can I say about this that hasn't already been said? An absolute timeless classic. If you haven't seen this, I suggest you stop what you're doing right now and go watch it.

So for my birthday, I got a 100 Movies Bucket List poster that consists of a variety of titles that also has a scratch-off sticker to reveal an image related to the movie (for Shawshank Redemption it was the small rock pick). As a challenge for myself, I have decided to watch and write reviews for each of these 100 movies starting from top to bottom. And at the top of the list was Shawshank Redemption.

This movie was adapted from a Stephen King novel which surprisingly enough, wasn't about something horrific. I knew he wrote other movies that didn't have supernatural elements like the Green Mile, but I didn't know that this movie was any different. All that I knew going into the movie was that the leads were Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman and that it was about a man who was innocent but given a life sentence. The only reason I knew that was because of the film synopsis though, so I'd say I went in pretty blind.

I think I would've preferred the film synopsis to say something different than that though because it could've just said that Andy has been given a life sentence in prison but it also would have avoided saying he was innocent. This would have been a good reveal later in the movie when it is finally revealed to us as the viewer. I mean the back of the Stephen King novel says that the book is about "a fiercely compelling convict named Andy Dufresne, who is seeking his ultimate revenge." Either way, just make sure your film synopsis doesn't spoil the actual movie. But don't worry, you'll have plenty to be shocked about.

This film doesn't shy away from dark plot developments, which helps the movie stay interesting while also providing world-building for life in the Shawshank prison. From the first scene within Shawshank, we see a new inmate named "Fat-A**" get beaten to death upon his first night there. And although we don't know if he died right away, just the fact that the guards just left him there to die was just shocking. So within our first 5 minutes within Shawshank, we are introduced to cold-blooded murder.

Another thing to consider when talking about these dark plot developments is the film's inclusion of the issues of institutionalization. Institutionalization is defined as the act of establishing something as a convention or norm in an organization or culture. If you need an example, take the death of "Fat-A**" because most of the inmates upon hearing that he died, were not surprised. They see inmates dying at the hands of Hadley as normal, as they have probably experienced it enough times to not question why. 

This creates disconnects with Brooks and Red when they are introduced back into society outside of Shawshank. When Brooks leaves, he admits that he misses his pet crow Jake and his job as the prison librarian, as it gave him purpose within that society. The only purpose the new society gave Brooks was to bag groceries, and even people belittle him for not doing a good enough job. As he gets lonelier and lonelier, he starts to think about committing a crime to go back to prison, but he ultimately chooses suicide to end his turmoil. 

Red's return was a bit different though because he knew Andy left something for Andy outside the walls of Shawshank, and all he had to do was find it. This simple task gave Andy a purpose, a purpose that Brooks simply didn't have. And that purpose gave Red hope, hope for a meaningful rest of his life, hope for finding his old friend, and hope for true freedom. 

In fact, this entire movie's theme is that hope makes you alive, and that it is the one thing that people can't take away from you. This is shown through the constant struggles of the main character Andy trying to make everyone's lives better within the prison, and holding onto the hope that one day he will be proven innocent for the crime he didn't commit. This hope that he carries throughout the movie keeps him from breaking down crying like other new inmates, so instead, he channels his focus onto making the prisoners feel hopeful again. 

Among these acts, Andy helped make a better prison library, played music for all the inmates, and convinced the prison guards to give his friends a cold beer. My favorite act though was Andy helping inmates with their high school equivalency test. This was because we got to see the impact that Andy had on individuals within Shawshank, like how he helped Tommy. Tommy became hopeful for his future, and to see him believe that he could be more than just a criminal, was amazing to see. And we too as the audience felt just as proud as Andy did when Tommy passed.

But we all know now that Tommy dies right after he passes his high school equivalency test. Now I shouldn't have been too shocked when the warden kills Tommy but I was naive to think that the warden would let Tommy set Andy free. So when I saw it on screen, my jaw dropped to the floor, not because I was shocked by the warden's actions but mostly because I felt so bad for Tommy. This movie doesn't shy away from gruesome death scenes, and they make you feel sadness (like for Brooks and Tommy) but also joy when the warden finally commits suicide later on in the movie. The deaths have such an impact on the story that if this movie didn't have them, I think it would be worse because of it.

But Tommy's death wasn't the only twist in this movie because we haven't talked about Andy's great escape. So before Andy's getaway, he got 6 feet of rope from a friend, and Andy never specified what he would use it for. The movie kept us from predicting what would happen by misleading us from the true events, and it does it in two ways. The first is that the movie told us that escaping by using the rock pick was impossible, they even made Red laugh at how long it would take to mine a hole through the wall with that kind of pickaxe. So when he escapes by using the pickaxe, we aren't expecting it. The second way was by making all the characters believe that Andy was going to take his own life with the rope, making us expect that he will be hanging himself that night as well.

So when it is revealed to us that Andy escaped through a hole in the wall, we feel shocked as the warden when we see the long tunnel that Andy dug to get out of Shawshank. After this, Red narrates how Andy succeeded in his plan to get out of Shawshank, and the plan explained a lot about Andy's behavior. His confident walk around the prison yard? He was dumping gravel through his pant legs to be discrete. The posters? To block the main hole from being seen, and the other posters to lead attention away from the one guarding the hole. Andy thought of everything and although it took a whopping 19 years to dig that hole, he made it out. 

If you tell me you weren't smiling while Andy was basking in the glory of freedom while being soaked by the rain, I don't know what to tell you. That moment was absolutely glorious. It was like all the worries and troubles that Shawshank had given Andy were being washed away by the rain. Absolutely beautiful.

Now the character of Andy Dufresne was brought to life by Tim Robbins. He was an actor I was unfamiliar with when I watched this movie, but now I look forward to when I'll see him again. Just by his face alone, I always believed him to be deep in thought but since the narration is from Red, his thoughts are kept secret from us, unless he tells someone else about them. If I didn't know he was innocent because of the film synopsis, I don't think I could've told you that Andy was innocent or not because although he looked like a regular man, he spoke like a very intelligent man who always knew what people thought of him. Heck, even Red was saying how confident he looked for being such a regular man.

Speaking about Red, Red was played by Morgan Freeman. Don't worry guys, I promise I know who Morgan Freeman is so you don't have to be worried about my lack of film education, but man Morgan Freeman is so dang good at his job. When I listen to him speak one sentence, his tone alone is so engaging that it just demands that you listen. Hearing him narrate the entire movie from Red's perspective was a great directorial decision as without it, I wonder how much of the movie would really work. 

But this movie does work, and it makes me so happy to say that I think that this movie is a masterpiece. It made me feel all sorts of emotions from happiness and sadness, it made me laugh, and it kept me thinking about institutionalization even after I finished the movie. This movie was written and directed by Frank Darabont, so I say thank you sir for making this movie. Although I know many people won't read this, I love to think that in some way I'm doing you amazing people a service by watching and reviewing your movie. Even if it is a small gesture.

10/10 Thanks to everyone who worked on this project, it was amazing.

There's no doubt that The Shawshank Redemption is one of the defining films of the 1990s, and deservedly so.  It deals with the importance of individuality, our inherent need for friendship, perseverance, and undying hope, as well as the little victories we strive for under an oppressor's thumb.  Seemingly insignificant incidents over the course of the film have meaning we can't understand until the climax of an intricately woven plot.  On top of that, the acting is top-notch from start to finish, especially Morgan Freeman in the best role of his career.  The only possible criticism would be the fact that the film, at times, is openly manipulative as the music swells at all the right times to tell the viewer how to feel instead of just letting the audience make up its own mind on how to react emotionally to a given scene.  A minor quibble about an otherwise excellent movie.

The Shawshank Redemption, directed & written by Frank Darabont, is a definitive top twenty-five movie of all time. With the chemistry Darabont has with Niki Marvin & Stephen King, he decided to take a homerun-swing on Rita Hayworth & Stephen King's book. Niki Marvin may only have two below average movies coming into this movie, but she constructed this beautifully crafted picture, being nominated by the Academy Awards for Best Picture.

I have seen hundreds of movies in my time, and I'd arguably say that Frank Darabont had one of the best senses of direction; everything just flowed perfectly together, creating this fantastic crime/drama. The story was a brilliantly told, fresh & original take on a jail bird story, being flawlessly paced out, keeping everyone engaged at all times! The overall message of hope & optimism, spoke to so many different levels, giving this movie great layers of depth. The only nitpicks I had with the story, some set ups, and scenes were a little cliché, but tremendously easy to overlook.

Deborah Aquila did a great job casting this talented bunch of actors. You can tell all of the characters were invested so much into their roles, to the point where it felt like they were actual prisoners. This was my personal favorite performance by Morgan Freeman. His character is intuitive & so full of knowledge, being a positive figure the prisoners look up to. His character development was the best out of all of the characters, connecting us to his character more & more as the acts go on. Tim Robbins was a diamond in the rough casting. Sure, he's had a few good performances, but nothing before nor after holds up to his performance here. Morgan Freeman & Tim Robbins' characters are basically cut out of the same cloth. Robbins put on such a star studded performance, being so optimistic & witty. His character development is so pure, it's nothing short of genius, making it so easy to get behind his character, and root for him. Seeing Bob Gunton in this movie, being more than a plot device like his previous titles, was pretty exciting. He showed off his talent when the lights were the brightest, putting on a great performance. James Whitmore stood out the most, out of the side characters. His character may not have meant the most initially, but his character development becomes a big part in the overall message. The characters as a whole were very enjoyable, although having a few characters with predictable personalities.

The screenplay by Frank Darabont was outstanding! There was so many pieces of dialogue that spoke to high levels, being super clever, and sliding in a few laughs here and there.

The score by Thomas Newman (who went on to be one of the most accomplished composers), was an absolute masterpiece on it's own. Newman originalized this style of dramatic & haunting score, adding great tention to each scene.

Overall, this movie did everything almost flawlessly. Another movie to see before you die !

From Andy Dufresne's (Tim Robins) strong sense of optimism to Redding's (Morgan Freeman) unwavering loyalty, The Shawshank Redemption is a classic that offers it viewers more than what meets the eye. When Dufresne is charged with the murder of his wife and her lover, he was found guilty and convicted for a life time in a prison. Upon his arrival in prison, Redding takes a bet with his co-inmates: Dufresne would not be able to survive his first day in prison. Nonetheless, as the events unfold, what was perceived as a frail man turns out to be the strongest character one can imagine. From the onset, Dufresne was convinced of his innocence. It has to be the sincerity of Dufresne's claim that when met with unflinching hope paved his way towards freedom. The story of Dufresne, though in a subtle way, can be generalized in a sense that it highlights the shortcomings of criminal justice system where presumably an innocent can face severe consequences. It also highlights the inhumane treatment meted out to the prisoners as the proverbial adage "Hate the crime and not the criminal" dies a thousand deaths every single day across the prisons. By not portraying what is traditionally expected from a prison movie i.e. violence between inmates, the film certainly seeks to reveal the aforementioned subjects of greater social importance. It also shows that how hard the corrupt may try, he cannot fulfill his responsibilities in a proper way. By showing how Warden Norton (Bob Gunton) used Dufresne's expertise as an accountant to illicitly expand his wealth, the director alluded to Dufresne innocence in a way. By not being able to keep Dufresne incarcerated, Warden Norton's evil came in the way of his duty as the truth of Dufresne subsided the wickedness of Norton. Another important take away is the importance of loyalty as enunciated by the character of Red. Red tried many a time to win parole but was not able to do so. When he got impressed by the kind-heartedness of Dufresne, he befriended him. As selflessness is the fuel of a friendship, Dufresne portrayed exactly that when he negotiated bottles of beer –despite himself being a non-alcoholic– for his fellow inmates in lieu of handling tax matters of one of the captains of the prison.  The friendship that was a byproduct of these gestures was what helped Red get his parole eventually. When he got his parole, he kept his promise and followed the instructions of Dufresne, who already escaped the prison, and ultimately joined him on an island, where both lived as free men. The fact that Red chased Dufresne after getting his freedom shows his loyalty and that he was aware of the fact that Dufresne has inadvertently played a role in his parole. With all this said, The Shawshank Redemption indeed is more than just a classic. It draws the attention of viewers to messages such as the importance of integrity and loyalty while portraying the shabby picture of criminal justice system and the fate of prisoners.

The movie, which is based on the novel ‘Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption' by Stephen King, flows seamlessly in the 2 hours of screen-time. You can't be bored for a second. Surprisingly, Stephen King charged just one dollar for the movie rights.
The movie starts with Andy Dufresne, an investment banker, a logical mind (as it seemed in the courtroom scene), getting indicted for the murder of his wife for having an affair with a pro golfer. The movie becomes gripping when Andy is sent to Shawshank prison. In prison, Andy meets Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding ( Morgan Freeman) and his other friends. Andy who is a first-time offender finds it difficult to adjust to the insensitive environment of the prison and fight off Bogs, a prisoner who constantly tries to trouble Andy. The prison is run by wicked Warden Norton and Captain Headley. As the movie progresses, the depths of Andy's character are reflected ever-so bright. Andy is a smart banker, who would outplay you in every aspect of the game right when it's needed. He has a taste for good music and believes that music is something that can't be touched by an external force such as the prison authorities. He has a belief, a belief so strong that it can't be mended by the ‘hole' or Captain Headley. 
The brilliant narration by Red is the most crucial ingredient of the movie. The subtle narration flows smoothly through the varied scenes of the film. The narration's language is backed by the uncanny way of Morgan's story-telling. He doesn't speak words, he sings them with all the calm of the world. Morgan uses words and phrases to express emotions that you think of speaking out loud but can't because you simply can't describe it well enough. Red's narration in the background makes the movie so enjoyable, you could probably listen to its podcast if it ever came out. He gives life to the most epic scenes of the movie, from the "rooftop scene" to the climax. He fills it with the warmth of friendship and respect towards Andy. 
The relationship between Red and Andy Dufresne transcends the boundaries of conventional friendship. Red was more than a friend to Dufresne. From getting things from the outside to making him believe they were all innocent, Red was one guy Andy could always talk to. 
The story revolves around Andy and his uncanny way of handling troubles. Andy was just a bird who wasn't meant to be caged, his feathers were just too bright.  It was a sin to keep him there. Andy changed the whole perspective of Red and the viewers too. He taught us that there are things that no one can take from you, it is deep inside you. It is called Hope. And as Andy finally succeeds to make Red, along with the viewers, believe that hope is a good thing. The story unfolds with an essence of love and life in it. It is not a conventional prison escape, as you might expect, it is a once in a century movie that teaches you the little things of life, it relaxes you to immeasurable comfort, makes you forget your problems and gives you a memory that you will treasure and share with your loved ones forever. It is a movie that will live on forever.

For such a beloved and widely praised film I am surprised it took me so long to get around to watching it as I have seen far less popular 1990s Best Picture nominees such as The Thin Red Line (1998) and Shine (1996). I must say that it didn't quite grab me the way it must for those who proclaim it to be uplifting and heartfelt but maybe with repeat viewings I will be able to fully understand it's appeal. This is not to say that I did not enjoy the film and understand that it was an exceptionally well crafted piece of cinema with some lovely moments in amongst the overly cloying and emotionally manipulative ones.

In 1947, wealthy banker Andy Dufresne, Tim Robbins, is sentenced to life in prison after being wrongly convicted of murdering his wife and her lover. He proves himself to be resilient and patient in prison as he does not draw the ire of the prison guards and easily befriends the resourceful Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding, Morgan Freeman, who is able to smuggle items into the prison. Dufresne uses his skill as a banker to ingratiate himself with warden Samuel Norton, Bob Gunton, and gain privileges such as being able to retain a smuggled posters of sex symbols in his bedroom. He builds up a library over time and begins to discuss the prospect of escaping as one of his friends commits suicide when he finally leaves prison and the corruption of those running the prison gets worse. Dufresne and Redding never lose the will to keep living over the years and a seemingly miraculous event uplifts the two of them and provides them with inspiration to live out the dreams that they described to one another in prison.

Where the film finds itself is in exploring the bond that develops between groups of downtrodden people as they have a camaraderie built on mutual respect and the same fears which they discuss with rambunctious humor. Of course Dufresne's rise is slightly fantastical as it is shocking that a corrupt leader would allow an underling of very apparent intelligence this amount of access to valuable secrets that could easily be used against him. But there is such pleasure to be found in this wishful thinking as a kind group of men who are willing to put in the effort to gain the privileges that enrich their lives so much. Darabont's adaptation of Stephen King's short story onto the screen works nicely as it focuses in on these small interactions and never gets too lost in the espionage occurring in the background or the fights between the guards and the prisoners.

Robbins and Freeman also make fantastic leads as they are both incredibly likable while leaving a certain enigmatic quality alive in their characters. We never do know too much about these characters before their time in prison and because Redding appears to have been so young this makes sense, he really never lived before serving time, while our unease about Dufresne serves to put us in the headspace of the other prisoners. We are left to assume that he did not kill his wife and it was instead another man, a burglar known to a young prisoner whom Dufresne mentors, is responsible but he always remains somewhat at a distance from the other men and the audience. Redding speaks of him reverentially as a man of qualities to aspire to and even in their final meeting it is Dufresne who has shown Redding the way and who stands independent and self-sufficient on the beach. Fortunately this does not make us dislike him but allows us to understand some of the more ‘magical' elements of the film as it is Redding recounting the story and he does not view Dufresne as a normal man but a figure capable of extraordinary acts.

Elements of the film that I did not appreciate were the score which laid on the sentimentality thick and an unnecessary subplot in which a former prisoner commits suicide. Thomas Newman can bring enormous emotional depth to film's that lack in obvious visual symbolism and pathos but this is a very obviously sweeping and emotional film so it would have been nice to have a slightly more stripped down, restrained score to leave the audience some room to interpret the meaning of certain scenes for themselves. The suicide subplot felt the most false of all of the emotional strands in the film and I would have liked to see an issue with as much importance and pain attached to it treated with more respected and not milked for an emotional response from the audience.

Frank Darabont's prison drama The Shawshank Redemption (1994) will bring you to tears as its simple honesty and brutal trauma explore the prison industrial complex. Stephen King's story is a profound and timeless parable on the effects of political corruption, police brutality, legal loopholes, and prison life. You will find someone to relate to herein as The Shawshank Redemption remains one of the greatest films of all time because it champions hope, bravery, kindness, empathy, friendship, and freedom. King's writing is brilliant and poignant with realistic drama stemming from horrendous cruelty and glaring flaws within the justice system. The Shawshank Redemption is an apt companion to The Green Mile, Escape from Alcatraz, and Cool Hand Luke.

Darabont's direction is stellar as he keeps your attention in every scene. You are completely swept into Shawshank's gritty world of broken men. Darabont finds new ways to coherently tell King's compelling story, so that you are always intrigued at where the story is going. Roger Deakins' cinematography is stunning and warm with many of his most clever shots herein. A shot looking down from the sky with a man's arms to represent freedom is absolute genius. Thomas Newman's score is riveting as it only chimes in to reaffirm The Shawshank Redemption's mysterious, intense, scary, or emotional sequences. Newman elevates a gorgeous film into a moving one.

Tim Robbins is perfect as the intelligent lead Andy Dufresne. Robbins portrays one of cinema's most thoughtful, pensive, and sympathetic figures with an empathetic face, eyes, voice, movement, and persona. Robbins is as brilliant in The Shawshank Redemption as he is in Mystic River. Robbins is a phenomenal actor because he depicts large themes in subtle displays of acting.

Morgan Freeman is as affecting as Robbins because Freeman gives his inmate, Red, a distinct air of hopelessness. His character has given up until he befriends the optimistic and motivated Dufresne. On the other hand, Bob Gunton is brutal and vile as the revoltingly corrupt and cruel Warden Samuel Norton. He knows how to appear fearsome without screaming. His quiet fuming and purposeful vindictiveness is astounding as Gunton acts to peak villainy.

Overall, The Shawshank Redemption is a revelation in allowing an audience to empathize with prisoners on a personal level. You should watch it as I'm certain you will love it.

This movie is long and plodding. It gives you a lot to comprehend, a lot to digest and a lot to think about once it's done. It does not spoon feed you information and it allows for viewers to truly become immersed in the story. Based on the novella by Stephen King, we get to witness a master class in storytelling, character development and an early example of plot twists coming out of nowhere. Following the unlucky story of Andy Dufresne as he navigates the brutal, unforgiving life of a maximum security prison inmate, we get to watch this brilliant former banker manipulate his way through the system and leave those in charge believing they have him by the short and curlies when in reality he was playing them like instruments the whole time. On his journey, he is joined by Red, a man who can get things and is always there to lend a helping hand, ear or advice whenever needed. We also meet Brooks, an elderly man who has spent the majority of his life incarcerated within Shawshank's walls. As the story unfolds, we watch as Brooks leaves the prison, only to become entrenched in that life even on the outside. It leads him to suicide in a scene that is as heart-wrenching as it is educational (showcasing the downside of long terms in prison and becoming institutionalized). We also lay witness to Andy weaselling himself in to the financials of the prison and creating a persona that technically does not exist. Everything culminates in the escape of the century, a man desperate for freedom crawling through the sewage pipe, not knowing what is on the other side, not caring just wanting out. Red so poignantly states, "He crawled through 500 yards of shit and came out clean on the other side." This is a movie that needs to be on everybody's to watch list.

It is a strange comment to make about a film set inside a prison, but "The Shawshank Redemption" creates a warm hold on our feelings because it makes us a member of a family. Many movies offer us vicarious experiences and quick, superficial emotions. "Shawshank" slows down and looks. It uses the narrator's calm, observant voice to include us in the story of men who have formed a community behind bars. It is deeper than most films; about continuity in a lifetime, based on friendship and hope.

Interesting that although the hero of the film is the convicted former banker Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), the action is never seen from his point of view. The film's opening scene shows him being given two life sentences for the murder of his wife and her lover, and then we move, permanently, to a point of view representing the prison population and particularly the lifer Ellis 'Red' Redding (Morgan Freeman). It is his voice remembering the first time he saw Andy ("looked like a stiff breeze would blow him over"), and predicting, wrongly, that he wouldn't make it in prison.
From Andy's arrival on the prison bus to the film's end, we see only how others see him - Red, who becomes his best friend, Brooks the old librarian, the corrupt Warden Norton, guards and prisoners. Red is our surrogate. He's the one we identify with, and the redemption, when it comes, is Red's. We've been shown by Andy's example that you have to keep true to yourself, not lose hope, bide your time, set a quiet example and look for your chance. "I guess it comes down to a simple choice, really," he tells Red. "Get busy livin' or get busy dyin'."

The key to the film's structure, I think, is that it's not about its hero, but about our relationship with him - our curiosity, our pity, our admiration. If Andy had been the heroic center, bravely enduring, the film would have been conventional, and less mysterious. But we wonder about this guy. Did he really kill those two people? Why does he keep so much to himself? Why can he amble through the prison yard like a free man on a stroll, when everyone else plods or sidles?

People like excitement at the movies, and titles that provide it do well. Films about "redemption" are approached with great wariness; a lot of people are not thrilled by the prospect of a great film - it sounds like work. But there's a hunger for messages of hope, and when a film offers one, it's likely to have staying power even if it doesn't grab an immediate audience.

"The Shawshank Redemption" premiered at the Toronto Film Festival in September 1994, and opened a few weeks later. It got good reviews but did poor business (its $18 million original gross didn't cover costs; it took in only another $10 million after winning seven Oscar nominations, including best picture).

There wasn't much going for it: It had a terrible title, it was a "prison drama" and women don't like those, it contained almost no action, it starred actors who were respected but not big stars, and it was long at 142 minutes. Clearly this was a movie that needed word-of-mouth to find an audience, and indeed business was slowly but steadily growing when it was yanked from theaters. If it had been left to find its way, it might have continued to build and run for months, but that's not what happened.
Instead, in one of the most remarkable stories in home video history, it found its real mass audience on tapes and discs, and through TV screenings. Within five years, "Shawshank" was a phenomenon, a video best seller and renter that its admirers feel they've discovered for themselves. When the Wall Street Journal ran an article about the "Shawshank" groundswell in April 1999, it was occupying first place in the Internet Movie Database worldwide vote of the 250 best films; it's usually in the top five.

Polls and rentals reflect popularity but don't explain why people value "Shawshank" so fervently. Maybe it plays more like a spiritual experience than a movie. It does have entertaining payoff moments (as when the guards from another prison, wearing their baseball uniforms, line up to have Andy do their taxes). But much of the movie involves quiet, solitude, and philosophical discussions about life. The moments of violence (as when Andy is sexually assaulted) are seen objectively, not exploited.

The movie avoids lingering on Andy's suffering; after beatings, he's seen in medium and long shot, tactfully. The camera doesn't focus on Andy's wounds or bruises, but, like his fellow prisoners, gives him his space.

The Morgan Freeman character is carrier of the film's spiritual arc. We see him at three parole hearings, after 20, 30 and 40 years. The first hearing involves storytelling trickery; the film has opened with Andy's sentencing, and then we see a parole board, and expect it's about to listen to Andy's appeal. But, no, that's when we first see Red. In his first appeal he tries to convince the board he's been rehabilitated. In the second, he just goes through the motions. In the third, he rejects the whole notion of rehabilitation, and somehow in doing so he sets his spirit free, and the board releases him.
There's an underlying problem. Behind bars, Red is king. He's the prison fixer, able to get you a pack of cigarettes, a little rock pick or a Rita Hayworth poster. On the outside, he has no status or identity. We've already seen what happened to the old librarian (James Whitmore), lonely and adrift in freedom. The last act, in which Andy helps Red accept his freedom, is deeply moving - all the more so because Andy again operates at a distance, with letters and postcards, and is seen through Red's mind.

Frank Darabont wrote and directed the film, basing it on a story by Stephen King. His film grants itself a leisure that most films are afraid to risk. The movie is as deliberate, considered and thoughtful as Freeman's narration. There's a feeling in Hollywood that audiences have short attention spans and must be assaulted with fresh novelties. I think such movies are slower to sit through than a film like "Shawshank," which absorbs us and takes away the awareness that we are watching a film.

Deliberate, too, is the dialogue. Tim Robbins makes Andy a man of few words, quietly spoken. He doesn't get real worked up. He is his own man, capable of keeping his head down for years and then indulging in a grand gesture, as when he plays an aria from Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro." (The overhead shot of the prisoners in the yard, spellbound by the music, is one of the film's epiphanies.) Because he does not volunteer himself, reach out to us or overplay his feelings, he becomes more fascinating: It is often better to wonder what a character is thinking than to know.

Roger Deakins' cinematography is tactful, not showy. Two opening shots, one from a helicopter, one of prison walls looming overhead, establish the prison. Shots follow the dialogue instead of anticipating it. Thomas Newman's music enhances rather than informs, and there is a subtle touch in the way deep bass rumblings during the early murder are reprised when a young prisoner recalls another man's description of the crime.

Darabont constructs the film to observe the story, not to punch it up or upstage it. Upstaging, in fact, is unknown in this film; the actors are content to stay within their roles, the story moves in an orderly way, and the film itself reflects the slow passage of the decades. "When they put you in that cell," Red says, "when those bars slam home, that's when you know it's for real. Old life blown away in the blink of an eye. Nothing left but all the time in the world to think about it." Watching the film again, I admired it even more than the first time I saw it. Affection for good films often grows with familiarity, as it does with music. Some have said life is a prison, we are Red, Andy is our redeemer. All good art is about something deeper than it admits.

It doesn't have the technical wizardry of some blockbusters never mind the multi-million action set pieces. 
It is the relationship that develops between the primary characters. In this case life sentence prisoners at Shawshank Prison.
The film has a timeline of some twenty years or so. It begins with the intake of new prisoners including Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) and the ingenious way he adapts to his multiple life sentence for murder. Even more so when he is innocent as well.
Not only does he have to survive the homosexual advances of some fellow inmates but the strict bible bashing Warden that has some elements of the Patrick McGoohan character in Escape from Alcatraz.

Is it bad that I watched this and thought it was based on a true story...

and then was severely disappointed that it wasn't? It was actually based off a book by Stephen King titled "Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption" and from what I read online, it follows the book fairly well. Still, when I was watching the movie I was holding off on my annoyance on just how cliche the film really was. 

The twist was spectacular and it left me with a wide-ass grin on my face. But with the knowledge that it's all from a book, the scene with the giant oak tree and Red trying to find the rock now sounds goes from neat to pretty stupid. The entire time I was thinking if this were in the real world and not a movie, there's no way in hell I'd find that rock in just a few scene montages with one song playing in the background while wearing a damn suit in that summer heat. But movies gotta movie and well... he finds it alright. And then just based off of a note and a few hundred dollars, he finds a way to cross the border as a parole evading convict and find Andy somewhere in Zihuatanejo. I wish it was as easy as Morgan Freeman makes it.

Another aspect of the film that got ruined for me with my book realization was Tommy William's role. I thought that it was extremely convenient that Andy would happen to be teaching the only person alive who could prove his innocence. And to make the movie more dramatic, Warden Samuel Norton refused to let Andy go to trial so he had Tommy killed while inhumanely locking Andy up in solitary confinement for two months. It seems to be a popular thing for wardens in films to be power abusing assholes, doesn't it?

Regardless of all of that, The Shawshank Redemption was still a very entertaining film with great storytelling (I mean it is Morgan Freeman narrating) and with one of the best twists to a film ever! Well worth the watch just for that.

As most of us know, Stephen King is quite an interesting fellow. His movie adaptations haven't always been well received, perhaps due to the fact that most people don't relate well to his bizarre creations. 
The Shawshank Redemption, however, is simply an incredible film. There are (many) reasons why some of the most respected critics rave about this film. 
The Director, Frank Darapont, beautifully captured the essence of King's storytelling in this edge-of-your-seat rollercoaster. 
Maybe it's the connections you find yourself identifying with throughout the film.  The film was filled with some incredibly talented actors, a group that worked very well together having numerous stellar portrayals. Perhaps it's the way Frank Darabont tugs at your heart strings with hope, friendship and the meaning of life. This film truly touches on all the "deep stuff" in life. Watching this film for the first time was like discovering a newfound sense of meaning, I left uplifted with a sense of boundless gratitude, ready to take on the world! I feel that certain films that move you to feel certain emotions are among some of the most powerful. The Shawshank Redemption is well-deserving of such a description. 
Tim Robbins shines as Andy Dufresne- a skinny young banker from Maine. To Dufresne's unfortunate luck, he is accused of killing his cheating wife and her lover. His promises and cries of innocence in court don't carry much weight, but his shy manner and likable personality do. Andy soon makes friends at Shawshank Prison with "Red", played by Morgan Freeman. Red is a veteran con who takes an authoritative position at Shawshank. Andy soon draws a circle of prisoners around him, and before he knows it has quite the group of friends. One of which, played by James Whitmore, plays an elderly man who will certainly toy with your emotions at some point in the film. 
There's a reason why this film is constantly on "Top 10 Movies of all Time" lists. A must see for all.

"The Shawshank Redemption" Movie Review

A typical prison movie consists of bad food, dirty surroundings, and physically abusive inmates and guards, while "The Shawshank Redemption" takes this genre to a completely different level. While still including the filth and violence, emotion plays a bigger role. When directing the movie, Frank Darabont ought to have wanted to hit the entire spectrum of emotion. During the movie, the audience will feel themselves cheering from the couch, irritated, or holding back a few tears.
 
Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) is convicted of killing his wife and the man she was cheating on him with, and he is sentenced to two consecutive life sentences. While serving his sentences Andy meets Red (Morgan Freeman), who slowly becomes one of his greatest strengths. Andy uses his previous banking skills to get a job in prison that he enjoys and passes his time with hobbies and devious schemes. The movie, "The Shawshank Redemption" is made perfectly using strategic acting and not to forget about how basic the setting is.

Tim Robbins does a fantastic job playing the main character, Andy Dufresne. He captivates the audience and keeps them watching his every move. He creates a walk and a way of speech for his character. I watched an interview of Tim Robbins shortly after the film was released, and I took special notes of the way that he walked into the room and his tone of voice. He talks softly and walks as if he holds himself up a little higher than he does anyone else when he is not playing the part of Andy Dufresne. During the movie, he walks with more of a lost-like stroll and speaks in a deeper, seductive sound. 

For a movie filled with drama, "The Shawshank Redemption" has the most basic special effects. The story took place in The Shawshank Prison for the majority of the movie, so the only props and backgrounds consisted of brick walls, dirty floors, and rusted metal bars. The simplicity of the special effects not only contradicted with the action-filled plot, but it was able to bring the audience into the movie. Everyone can relate to being in a room with brick walls wanting to break free because of how lonely you may feel, which is exactly how the inmates felt.  

While the special effects and the props are basic, the plot of "The Shawshank Redemption" could not have been more exciting. The actors did a phenomenal job at pulling the audience into the movie and making them feel like they are there with the actors. Not only does the movie entertain the audience for a little over two hours, but it also educates the typical movie-goers on some issues in prisons in the past. At the time the wardens of prisons were finding scandalous ways to make profits and keep the money for themselves instead of using it for their jobs like they should have been doing. The purpose of this movie was to pass on the tale of the famous prison escapee and to shame the prison systems.

One of the most renowned films ever made, The Shawshank Redemption can easily be found in most top 10 movie lists. But does it deserve the praise? In short, absolutely. What Frank Darabont has developed for the silver screen is completely breathtaking. First and foremost, you have the strength of the two leads. Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman's chemistry is so infectious that you are begging for more with each passing line of dialogue they share. These two lost, beaten down souls finding hope and the will to live is beautifully executed.

Of course you can't forget about the other actors. The casting is pitch perfect, with special attention to Bob Gunton and Clancy Brown as the antagonistic warden and prison guard. Despite the warden bordering on being an over the top, unrealistic cartoon, Gunton's performance makes it very watchable.

But perhaps the truly greatest achievement of this film is the grand scale of it. While the majority of the narrative takes place inside a prison, you get the sense that it's a whole world of its own; almost a character itself. You watch it age over the years, losing and gaining new prisoners and their changing personalities, exploring every nook and cranny of it. In many ways, the prison is claustrophobic and small but it's also huge and epic. This added element, which engulfs the viewer in its atmosphere, makes the film all the more engaging.

More than 20 years later, Shawshank still holds up incredibly well and is fully deserving of its praise. If there are any complaints, some of the story beats and characters come off as somewhat clichéd and hokey considering how many these elements have become more prominent in the passing years (Morgan Freeman as the wise mentor and narrator, the crazed religious authority figure, the power of friendship and hope, etc.). 

Still, the cast and crew's obvious passion put into the final product is highly commendable and elevates the material to a whole new level. Be sure to check this excellent movie out.

Frank Darabont's The Shawshank Redemption (1994) focuses on both physical and mental architectures of confinement, as well as the role of religion in terms of human behavior. The movie tells the story of Andy Dufresne who gets sent to Shawshank Prison for a crime he hasn't committed, meets Red, struggles through the prison life, and finally manages to escape only to be reunited with Red later at Zihuatanejo. With these three themes brought together, and using camera angles, music, and narrative dialogues, the movie transcends a view of how life is really like be it within, or without, the walls of Shawshank.


The inmates of Shawshank prison are put in physical confinement the moment they enter. Their autonomy is taken away, and they become like animals in a cage. This is made clear when Hadley tells the inmate, "You eat, when we say you eat. You shit, when we say you shit, and you piss, when we say you piss" (00:13:45). The inmates forget what it's like to be free. This is further implied when Red explains to the others how Brooks became "institutionalized" (00:59:12), and that the walls of the prison were all what he knew. Institutionalization is a concept that is not necessarily witnessed when inside prison. It happens whenever there is some sort of deprivation of freedom, which leads to people forgetting what it's really like to be free. When Red is released, he asks for permission to go to the bathroom, which is something that no human can be deprived off, yet this is just the case with the inmates. Institutionalization can sometimes occur to people without them noticing it as they simply "go with the flow", only to realize later that they are nothing but machines following a certain routine dictated by a higher system. In addition, Red also says, "They send you here for life, and that's exactly what they take," (01:00:17) indicating that the physical confinement didn't merely act at the level of freedom, but rather at the level of simply existing. In a metaphoric way, this is how many people actually "live" their entire lives. They spend their lives first worrying and fussing about studies, then work, then marriage, then children, only to reach the end of their lives realizing that they haven't been really "living". Again, they were only following the physical limitations of an already-dictated system.

The inmates are also put in a more serious mental confinement. Their spirits have no hope and they are filled with fear, which holds them prisoners. This line between fear and hope is drawn elaborately in the movie. Andy's character is nothing but the rock that Red dug under the tree at the end of the movie (02:14:00). Andy was the "rock that had no earthly business in a Maine Hayfield" (01:56:44); he "had an invisible coat that shielded him from this place" (00:28:50). He tries to instill the idea of hope within the spirits of his friends, especially Red and Tommy. He goes on to play the Mozart piece sung by the 2 Italian ladies, depicting a sign of fearlessness, all the while adding a sense of mental freedom to the inmates. This diegetic music brings all inmates, along with the audience, to a tentative and soothed state. Andy's hope is the reason to his eventual physical and mental freedom. An important scene where a line is drawn between fear and hope is towards the end of the movie, when the warden is seen to have given up on hope, and that did not work out well for him. He fills several bullets in his revolver and points it at the door in hopes of fighting off the police. However, the light of hope is shut inside him, and he shoots a bullet through his head (02:03:48). At this scene, the camera focuses on his face, and sweat is seen leaving his forehead, taking with it the last drips of hope. Another scene where a clear distinction is made between fear and hope with aid of camera angles is the scene where the camera focuses on the gun then shifts to the compass (02:10:30). The audience first thinks that Red is going to commit suicide; however, the compass indicates his search for his friend. Also, the frame shot of "Brooks was here, so was Red" (02:16:45) draws a fine line between two characters with opposing views of hope and fear. The ultimate mental realization of hope is what allows the characters to be set free from their confinements. The calm elevating music during Red's search for the tree, and his journey to Zihuatanejo, helps in indicating that Red has slowly managed to fill his spirit with hope.


Another important aspect of the movie is its frequent references to religion when it comes to Warden Norton's character. His first rule to the inmates is "No blasphemy" (00:13:26). He's a good reader of the Bible, and has most of its verses memorized. These are traits of a pious man of good will; however, the warden is the most evil character in the movie. Why does he do it? It is known that throughout the history of mankind, and ever since the dawn of civilizations, religion has often been used as means of justifying evil deeds, or protecting those who commit the evil deeds. The warden does exactly that. He uses the Bible in order to shield his dark side, or perhaps to justify his evil deeds. Towards the end of the movie, Norton drops the Bible on the floor (02:02:30), and the camera view focuses on where the Bible lands: right next to his feet, indicating disrespect, degradation, and blasphemy! This can come as a surprise to some people, but this is the case with Jules Winnfield in Quentin Tarantino's Pulp Fiction, which was released only a few weeks after The Shawshank Redemption. Jules also uses references to the Bible and acts pious, when in fact he is nothing but a cold-blooded murderer. 

More than 20 years later, The Shawshank Redemption still stands as one of the movies that set a mark in the world of cinema. By diving into issues of confinement and religion, the movie manages to portray aspects that are present all around the world. These are aspects that were, are, and will remain in play throughout the course of humanity.

There are only a select few movies that I would say are genuinely perfect, but Shawshank Redemption is on that list. I literally cannot think of one thing that I would change in this movie. While I haven't seen the whole movie from start to finish in a long time, it is one of those films that snags me whenever I catch it on TV and I cannot change the channel. There's a lot of praise I could lavish on this film, and I would probably bore you to tears. Instead of exhausting the entire thesaurus of positive adjectives and adverbs let me just take a few sentences to try and explain why this film touches me so deeply. For starters, Shawshank manages to get us sympathizing with the protagonist from the very beginning. Despite the fact that we have no evidence presented to make us believe Andy's story, the courtroom scenes at the beginning are designed to make the prosecutor look overly aggressive and Andy look innocent, so we're on his side instantly. As a result we're going through this ordeal with him, and every harsh moment he suffers feels like a personal offense to me.

Next is probably the most shallow of my reasons for loving Shawshank, but it's the narration from the amazing Morgan Freeman. When the film reaches those moments where it could drag, instead we get to listen to his dulcet voice explaining what happened as we skip a section of time. Because of this I don't feel a single frame of film is wasted in the entire 2+ hours of the movie. But the big thing that pushes this film over the edge for me, into being one of my favorite films of all time, is the Redemption. I don't feel like I'm spoiling anything because it's in the title, but that conclusion makes my heart swell so much that I almost can't contain it. When a film takes you through the lowest depths of despair and suffering, but then has a redemptive and happy ending, it is something truly special. The highs become so much more enjoyable because the lows were so terrible. Again, I could write for days about the greatness of Shawshank Redemption, but I'll simply say WATCH IT! And if you've seen it, WATCH IT AGAIN! Every single time I see any segment of the film (even just the last few scenes) I feel like my time was not wasted.

The Shawshank Redemption 

	Frank Darabont's The Shawshank Redemption is not just the best film of 1994, (tie with Pulp Fiction) but also one of the best films of all time. This addicting cinematic experience successfully delivers a powerful film with an engaging story that you won't want to end.  
Based on Stephen King's novella Rita Hayward and Shawshank Redemption, this uplifting prison drama revolves around the friendship of two men who spend 20 years together. 
Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins. That sums it up. As good as the story is, it's hard to say it would work without these two magnificent performances. Freeman plays Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding, an inmate who has been at Shawshank State Penitentiary long before Andy Dufresne (Robbins) arrives. 
In 1947, Dufresne is convicted of murdering his wife and her lover. He pleads his innocence, but regardless is sentenced to two consecutive life sentences at Shawshank. You will feel deep sincerity for Dufresne, but it's for the best because that's when Freeman starts to narrate. 
As soon as Dufresne walks off the prisoner bus at Shawshank, Red doesn't think much of him. Red wagers a pack of cigarettes that Dufresne will be the first of the new inmates to sob during his first night locked up. Dufresne doesn't make a sound. 
This sequence is narrated with Freeman's impeccable storytelling voice, as is much of the film. The pace of the plot is perfectly accompanied by Freeman's remarkable tone. It's easy to underestimate the significance of his narration. His voice is our guide through their compelling journey. 
Dufresne recognizes that Red is able to smuggle in different types of contraband into the prison. He asks Red for a small rock hammer for his sculpturing hobby, and a poster of actress Rita Hayworth. The two quickly become friends. 
There are many moments throughout the film that show us how different Dufresne is from the other inmates. There is something about him. He sees things in a way others don't, and Red's narration helps paint a clear picture for the audience. 
	In 1949, Dufresne and Red are doing some rooftop work with other inmates. Dufresne overhears the intimidating prison guard, Captain Hadley (played convincingly by Clancy Brown) complaining about an inheritance, in which he has to pay taxes. Dufresne, a former banker, offers to help Hadley legally secure his money with the exchange for his friends to drink beer on the rooftop. 
	This leads to Dufresne providing tax services to other prison guards, eventually leading to him unwillingly helping the ruthless Warden Norton (Bob Gunton) in his illegal money-laundering scheme. 
	The film gives us an ironic balance of good versus evil. The good is Dufresne and Red; the evil is the Warden and Captain Hadley. The interactions between these characters are enjoyable, and create intriguing storylines. 
	 Darabont's direction is flawless and his pacing is excellent. He perfectly blends the plot with the years spent in prison. He uses quality transitions and looming shots that zoom into the center of the subject. This shows us the realism of prison in a compelling way. 
	The Shawshank Redemption gives us compelling direction and interesting writing, but it's overshadowed by the memorable performances and narration. This triumphant story shows the horrors of incarceration, yet offers satisfying redemption. 
	This 122-minute epic will engulf your mind and lock your emotions in a holding cell that you don't want to be free of any time soon. It feels like only a half hour, because the story is truly engaging. The Shawshank Redemption accomplishes cinematic history. Yes, it's that good.
