Andy Defresne was a prosperous man who lived a life of wealth and prestige as a successful banker until that one life-shattering night.  When his wife is found murdered along with her secret lover, Andy is strongly assumed the offender.  Without a strong alibi, the highly-esteemed banker is condemned to serve two life in prison sentences despite his firm plea of innocence.  Andy is forced to let go of everything he is used to and adjust to the prison lifestyle, one in which he is ill suited for.  During Andy Defresne's sentence the realities of prison become apparent when a few of atrocious prisoners become fascinated with him, leading to trouble for Andy.  Fortunately, Andy Defrense eventually adapts to this new surroundings, using the skills he acquired prior to his sentence to attract relationships with people you wouldn't expect.  If you're a fan of enticing dramas, The Shawshank Redemption(1994) is a must watch.  
The soundtrack to The Shawshank Redemption elevates scenes throughout the movie which already hold strong emotion.  The majority of the soundtrack is not flamboyant or flashy but carries a strong influence with its simplicity during critical scenes.  For instance, when Andy's prison cell is randomly inspected, soft violin sounds arise.  This hints that this encounter could be meaningful while allowing the actors' interaction to dominate the scene.  Thomas Newman, the composer, justifies the overall mood of the movie by gracefully incorporating subtle music to the film.
Interactions between the characters feel real and conceivable as natural dialogue is used throughout.  Tim Robbins portrays his character (Andy Defresne) brilliantly.  Andy Defresne's personality and personal attributes are uniquely different from every other character in a movie concerning life inside the walls.  He walks around the prison yard in a composed, self-assured manner as if he's one step ahead of the game, a trait few inmates possess.  Andy's initial weakness is shown through his slumped body language. and his eventual confidence can be seen clearly by the distinct look in his eyes.  Morgan Freeman (Red) adds a different, yet intriguing element to this film.  Freeman displays Red as a confident, content prisoner in the beginning of the film.  As time passes, Red becomes more questioning of what more there may be to life by acquiring a constant look in his eyes as if he is examining Andy's words of hope and its validity.
The Shawshank Redemption is a film that draws you in from its beginning and keeps you entertained until the very end.  Morgan Freeman's narration throughout the film is intriguing.  While the film offers intense and defining "action" scenes, it proves to have much deeper deceptive characteristics and activities rooted within.  The film presents us with a simple yet useful lesson when you feel your life is losing purpose, "Either get busy livin', or get busy dying".

In the world of cinema, there are two ways to categorize prison dramas. They can be considered effective or moving, rarely both. The Shawshank Redemption is the quintessential example of the perfect concoction of both themes. The way that this story is brought to screen from the beloved Stephen King novel plays out like an adventure through the eyes of a prisoner. When a movie takes the perspective of multiple characters it makes a story and the character's action all the more believable and even understandable. Through the eyes of Andy and Red, we understand the way they act and where they go with their actions and dialogue because they understand their surroundings. The way that these two interact with each other is what makes this movie so enjoyable. Their charisma and attitude are the motors that keep the story running and never fails to impress and fascinate. The reason I got so invested in the two leads is because of the way they bounced off of each other with quick and smart dialogue and the way they function in prison. Prison movies are very often trumped up pieces of garbage with a leading man who can't act, a story line which doesn't stand and set pieces which can bore you to tears. However, The Shawshank Redemption shows the world of film that no matter how overdone the subject, a good character and a good story can make any setting into a great film. 

Thus we meet Andy Dufresne. He is quiet, lean, not much to look at really and blessed with a somewhat icy persona at a first glance. But upon getting to know the man behind the dull and faded covers is one of the most rewarding experiences film can give you. Andy's withdrawn nature gives way to a tough, complex man who, while he is taken lightly at first, clings stubbornly to life and holds to the idea that a man can overcome any circumstances surrounding him if he is patient. He may not be blessed with Jason Statham's physique or the chiselled perfection of many other actors but Tim Robbins has real talent, a thing which is lacking in much of Hollywood today. He plays Andy perfectly, a quiet, demure individual who only opens up to those he chooses to after careful consideration. He doesn't talk himself up even though he is very smart, and he doesn't jeopardise his plans by blabbing them out to every passerby. He has a quiet strength which is priceless in a situation like the one he finds himself in.

Red, too, is a great character. A prisoner who doesn't believe in hope, an unusual occurence for a prison film. His narration, which could be perceieved as lazy storytelling, gives great insight into the character's secret thoughts and emotions. Morgan Freeman, as usual, is spot on in his portrayal of the 'man who can get things.' 

These two great characters are just the tip of the iceberg for this movie, as every character on screen is filled with rich backstory and as complex as a real person. This gives a film which would otherwise be average an edge over all of the others in its genre. 

The film refuses to be rushed, taking its own time to unfold stories and show you different characters, though it is never boring and each scene brings some new insight into character's lives and into themselves. Whilst another film would have focussed on very different aspects of prison life, this one focusses on the prisoners inside. At the same time, however, this film goes where many films refuse to, as our hero is degraded in the worst way possible time and time again. The film does this with a certain elegance, however, not simply glossing over the fact, but not making it a focus point either. The story itself is fantastic, a coming of age story almost; the story of a man finally deciding to take initiative and do what he needs to. 

There are standout performances all around from James Whitmore, William Sadler, Clancy Brown and Bob Gunton, though Tim Robbins' restraint throughout the film is the most standout of them all. 

No focus has been lost on the technical aspects either, with some stunning cinematography (see the helicopter panning shot around the spires of the majestic Shawshank Prison. Beautiful) and lighting is impeccable. The music, too is perfectly suited for the film, beginning with an old, scratched record playing a song from around the time the film was set in. 

The themes evident here are some very poignant ones; displaying crooked wardens for all their greed, startling moments of conspiracy, the injustice in the system and above all, hold onto hope. 

The Shawshank Redemption is an amazing film which is so inspirational, you can't help but to be moved by it.

There have been a handful of movies set in a prison over the years. Some comedies, a lot of dramas - all of them sharing certain elements. One that tends to stand out from most others is the 1994 best picture nominee 'The Shawshank Redemption,' which is at its heart about the power of friendship and perseverance in the face of adversity. Set in mid-20th century Maine, 'Shawshank' looks at how two very different men (portrayed by Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins) can develop a friendship and make differences in the lives of their fellow inmates through regular acts of kindness in a federal prison. The film has all the makings of a classic, from solid, smart dialogue to bursts of drama and a quality soundtrack. The ups and downs experienced by both Robbins' character, Andy Dufresne, and Freeman's character, 'Red' Redding, are both rewarding and painful. One of the greatest strengths of 'Shawshank' is its climax - one that is not exactly expected based on the progression of the film. As things can go from bad to worse, 'Shawkshank' demonstrates there is always the chance for redemption, which is apparent based on the film's namesake. 'The Shawshank Redemption' has already proven to stand the test of time, and it's likely it will continue to do so.

This was from a speech that I made for one of my college class, and what better way to tell about my favorite movie than to show my speech to Rotten Tomatoes where everyone who does read my reviews will see from what I thought of The Shawshank Redemption. It was a few years ago when I was bored and I didn't have anything else better to do. I was going through the internet in terms of movies, and when I was looking through a list of the best movies of all time, I saw Shawshank Redemption as the highest rating movie on IMDB. I was curious enough to rent it and see what made this movie special. When I was finished with the film, I was in shock and pretty much said to myself that this movie is a special one. I wanted to do this because everybody has their own favorite film, and it's probably different from everyone else's special film. So for me, I'm going to tell you why it's my favorite based on some aspects: plot and setting, characters and actors who portrayed them, and writing and direction.
    The Shawshank Redemption is based on a short story by Stephen King, a banker that has received a life sentence for killing his wife and her lover while intoxicated. Even though he says that he's innocent, no one believes him, and the story begins with him living his life in the Shawshank Prison. Now, I don't know how faithful it was to the source material, but the movie probably expanded on the short story. The plot elements going on whether it be the main character trying to make the best for himself in the prison, making friends, and dealing with three people that wants to do, well, horrible things to him like it typically goes in prison, can get you interested in what's going on. It takes place at the Shawshank Prison, which in real life is an actual place called the Ohio State Reformatory that takes place in Mansfield, Ohio, and it's actually a tourist attraction for people to visit the set of the film that it takes place.
    Tim Robbins plays Andy Dufresne, the banker that's in the prison who at the beginning of the film is spending his first days in prison. He acted like his life was over, and had nothing else to go back to other than his everyday life outside of prison. As the days go by, he briefly acted a little suspicious like he was holding something in, but only to end up being friends with a murderer name Red that's played by Morgan Freeman. He was more of a people-person who was the first person to be friends with the main character, while knowing who to trust and who to stay away from as he had been in prison for many years. He tried to get parole, but he failed to do so. He brought joy into the film, so it didn't make the movie too depressing. Showing from his eyes, he did have a few exhausting moments where he kept getting declined for parole. The movie has interesting characters like a greaser who's likable and intentionally full of himself and not bright that gets some character progression unlike the characters from Grease, I'm just kidding I haven't seen Grease for years and I don't remember much so don't kill me for those who are fans of the film. There's the warden who is a mysterious character that you don't know whether he's a good guy or not until later on. Then, there's  Brooks who has a pet bird and has lived in the prison for decades to the point that he wants to stay in it.
    Whenever the characters have conversations with each other, they talked about human stuff, whether it be girls, what they liked in the days before they went to prison, and tried to help out in any way that had been going on in the prison, which is thanks to the script by Frank Darabont. He directed and wrote other Stephen King adaptations like The Green Mile, which was one of my favorite childhood films that I grew up with, and The Mist, which I only remember the ending when I first saw it because it kind of traumatized me of how messed up that ending was. The dialogue was so genuine that I felt like the characters talking were actual people, and whether you think they deserve to be in prison is totally up to you, but at some point you do feel like some of the character's time had definitely been served. The direction is also great that the structure of the film never seemed to have a boring spot, and there was never a scene that was unnecessary to this movie, which is cool knowing the fact that it's 2 hours and 22 minutes long. There are scenes like when Brooks is out of prison that it could've easily have been taken out of the film, but it shows something that you don't typically see in a prison film, and that's the aftereffects of a person that has been serving in prison for decades that even one of the characters says that he's basically "institutionalized", and Brooks even has the thought of doing something illegal in order to go back to the Shawshank Prison. 
    If what I say doesn't convince you otherwise, there are top critics from Rotten Tomatoes like Roger Ebert from Chicago Sun-Times who says this, "If the film is perhaps a little slow in its middle passages, maybe that is part of the idea, too, to give us a sense of the leaden passage of time, before the glory of the final redemption.", and James Berardinelli that says, "The Shawshank Redemption is all about hope and, because of that, watching it is both uplifting and cathartic." Those were the reasons why The Shawshank Redemption is my favorite film: interesting story that doesn't bore the audience, three-dimensional characters that you learn enough about to the point that you want some of them to get out of prison, and the script and direction being top-notch that creates a film that everybody will talk about for a long time. When you come across The Shawshank Redemption on DVD, your favorite film, or  just found a film on the internet that interest you in free time, give it a watch or go back to it because you'll maybe get something out of it that causes you to ask your own friends to watch this film just like I'm informing you guys of my favorite movie with this speech.

Most prison dramas come across as pretty clichéd these days. The innocent convict and hero of the story is sent to a really brutal prison. There's usually a hard-ass prison guard to deal with, and a warden working to undermine our hero's efforts. There will be time spent in solitary confinement, and a prisoner, someone close to the our hero will likely be killed. We've seen it so many times before. But for good reason. The Graybar hotel is a great place to set a drama. Each convict's sordid history is potential fodder for a compelling story. So when we see characters in that setting grow and change for the better, we care about it, and when a character like Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) is sent to Shawshank prison and starts to shake things up, it's easy to connect to that character and root for him.

It certainly doesn't hurt when Tim Robbin's is playing the part either. Nor is it a problem when his best friend(Red) is played by Morgan Freeman. In fact, this story is narrated by Red, and usually the constant need to explain story points and character feelings with a voice over really bothers me. But this is Morgan Freeman, and that voice gets a pass!

Written and directed by Frank Darabont, and adapted from Stephen King's short story 'Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption', published in his compendium Different Seasons. This prison drama is a masterclass in good acting and it's done with a sensitive touch. It's one of the best King adaptations, and shows there was more to King than just horror works. In 1947, banker Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) is convicted for murdering his wife and her lover, and he's sent to Shawshank State Penitentiary to serve 2 life sentences. It's here that he meets contraband smuggler Ellis "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), who is serving a life sentence, but he's able to get Andy anything he needs. Andy soon wins the respect of Warden Samuel Norton (Bob Gunton), after Andy helps the prison guards with their finances, and Norton has Andy work with elderly librarian Brooks Hatlen (James Whitmore), but Andy lives in hope that one day he will leave Shawshank, but Red believes he'll never do it. It's a great drama, one of the best prison dramas ever made, it has some brilliant characters and some brilliant dialogue. It sadly didn't connect with audiences when it came out in cinemas, but thanks to VHS, it became a hit, and it's become of the best loved films of all time, and it's a film which manages to engage everytime.

The Shawshank Redemption is, to say the least, an uplifting film. Which seems a little bit odd since we're talking about a film set inside of a prison. The Shawshank Redemption is truly a story about friendship, and hope. Upon Andy arriving at the prison we see something very interesting. And that would various prisoner's reaction to Andy. This is one of the most unique things about the film because it leaves a sort of mysteriousness about Andy. Really makes you wonder why he keeps to himself, all the time? The end will have you feeling uplifted and... hopeful. The Shawshank Redemption is a carefully crafted film, and does more than just display the cruel prison life, but somehow also manages to fill us wiith optimism.

 "The Shawshank Redemption is the best movie I have ever seen because of its ability to capture raw emotion."

 I'm also going to elaborate on the three biggest reasons people dislike this movie.

 1. It's too slow.

 The Shawshank Redemption may be a tad slow, but it is justified. I believe director Frank Darabont wanted to show Andy's time at Shawshank by showing how slow prison time really is. Some movies are just slow; this movie does it for a deeper reason, adding to Shawshank's genius.

 2. Andy Dufresne barely shows emotion.

 Those people obviously didn't get what kind of character Andy was. Tim Robbins did this on purpose. Andy was quiet, mellow, and was obviously quite shocked and angry he was going to prison for a crime he didn't do. Did you really expect the man to jump up and start singing "Kumbaya"? No!  Oh yes your right, since these men in prison smoked, cursed, drank, and kept their eyes peeled in the shower room for potential rapists. That is not realistic at all. The film was based off a Stephen King novel entitled "Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption", and it was adapted to the screen by Frank Darabont. I have not read King's novel, so I came into the film blind and not having any pre-existing feeling towards the film. Darabont has written a film that explores the themes of hope, institutionalisation, corruption, and friendship. The main focus of the plot is the life of Andy Dufresne during his time in prison. Andy is simply a metaphor of hope. He is a walking beacon of hope in the prison, and we can see his effect he had on his environment and the prisoners inhabiting within it. Andy is the closest thing to the life of the outside world, which is why people, especially Red, seem to cling on to him. Hope is a powerful agent, and this film demonstrates that perfectly, without hope, we start to find reasons to not live. The thing that made the character, Andy, a great man and symbol is that he is described and narrated by the perspective of another man, which in this case is Red. If the film decided to be narrated by Andy, then it wouldn't work because naturally he himself wouldn't think that he was a symbol of hope to these prisoners, and if he did, then he would have just come off as egotistic and pretentious. The Shawshank Redemption, in a way, can also be seen as a friendship film, as that aspect of the film truly drives the film along. Seeing Andy and Red together, is so interesting and engaging as their relationship feels so organic and never at all forced. The film also explores the concept of institutionalisation, saying that it sucks the life out of a person and that all individuality and perception of freedom is diminished from their system. It truly is a scary outcome, and something that nobody would ever want for themselves. The little short segment in the middle of the film on Brooks could have easily been a misfire if it wasn't written very well. The character Brooks is the only figure in that prison that seems to be genuinely kind and loving, and to see what he has become in the real world is heartbreaking. It's also interesting to see that the guards themselves who are conventionally a symbol of good and virtue, is instead the most despicable of them all. The film looks at the Warden as the devil, someone who at first wouldn't look like one but ends up showing his true colors as the film goes on. The Warden is too clever to just reveal all of himself at the start, he has to draw both Andy and the audience in before inflicting any damage. I found that theory to be quite interesting. The dialogue in the film was fun to listen to, not only because it contained well written lines but that it also has meaning to it. Every little thing that is being said kind of relate itself to the themes that floats throughout the film. It may be a bit down you throat for some people, especially if they want something more edgier, but I felt that it was a great way of showing the audience that this film is not just something that we can experience once and never revisit again. Darabont wants us to go back to Shawshank prison, because it felt good going through it and that it brings out something us that we never truly anticipated before.

The Shawshank Redemption is Frank Darabont's first feature film, not counting Buried Alive. What Darabont has created is a wonderful prison drama that gives us something more than what is offered on it's surface. Darabont is trying to tell us with The Shawshank Redemption, to not give up on hope, and the film succeeded on that as I have heard many stories of people being completely touched by this and that they made a complete change on their perspective of life. Darabont consistently kept this film to feel optimistic, regardless of the events that transpire during the middle passages of the film. But Darabont didn't let it's optimism keep this from a being a great drama. There are still moments of pitfalls for the film's characters and they are treated with enough seriousness that we end sympathising for the victims, but like I said, the film's atmosphere has kept this optimism to it which in a way let's the film feel much more accessible and easier to connect with. At first the film may feel quite long, but that just makes the experience of prison feel more real and I think that is very important in order to sell the agony of time that he had to endeavor. Darabont was able to truly capture the horrors of prison. The film was able to create this sense of claustrophobia on Andy, whether be the size of his cell or that he is neither safe with the people around him, whether they are guards or inmates. It's as if he can't get out. Darabont has kind of made the prison itself seem like a character and that is tough to do.

The film's cinematographer was Roger Deakins and I praise this man's work, not just for The Shawshank Redemption but also for other films like Skyfall and his work with the Coen brothers. What Deakins have made for The Shawshank Redemption is very impressive. Deakins and Darabont clearly wanted this film to be in the eyes or perspective of a certain person looking back on his experience with a particular person, so therefore the film needed to feel more like a cinematic imagination or vision instead of keeping feeling grounded and organic, like as if we were standing next to these characters. The film contains still shots that doesn't require major movements from the camera other than the occasional zoom into a character's face, and the film also contains wonderful tracking shots when the film does start to move along. The film also has these beautiful helicopter shots and brilliant composition of crane shots. Deakins understands that this film has significant depth, and that also Andy doesn't particularly talk in abundance, with silent moments showing introspection. The film's image is lifeless when shooting in the prison, to create this contrast on when we do get a glimpse of the outside world. When the film takes place in prison, Deakins has created this feeling of claustrophobia in his shots, in order to really feel the suffocation that our protagonist is agonizing from. As we get closer and closer to the end of the film, the claustrophobia starts to shed itself away, representing freedom.

The film's score was handled by Thomas Newman. His work for this film is beautiful, at times it was close in making me cry as Newman really knows how to hit those sentimental notes. In understanding with Darabont's direction, he has given this film an optimistic approach and only in rare occasions does it show any sort of melancholy in it's score. The score here may not be the most unique or experimental work he has created, and it may not even be his best score, but nevertheless his work here is one of the main reasons why the film's power is so strong. The score was able to give off both the feeling of friendship and the power of living. The highlight of the score is the scenes with Brooks living in the outside world, as I have said before, this moment broke my heart and a lot of it had something to do with Newman's score. There was so much sorrow in it that it almost feel inevitable in it's outcome. There are a couple of scores here that feels similar to his future works like Road To Perdition and Revolutionary Road, but everyone has their trademarks.

During the speech about living and dying, would have you left feeling ambiguous about him, as he seems to be deciding on the path that he would be taking, and we don't truly find out his intentions until later on the film. Robbins at the beginning of the film trying to adjust to his life in this haunting prison is one of the best moments of his performance, because along with great direction and writing, there is so much more that needed to be known about this character as he has yet shown his true colors, and Robbins understood this by allowing introspection to take charge of character development. Morgan Freeman was great as Red, and he seems to be a representation of us if we ever personally have met Andy. It is Red that we truly feel connected to because he is the only one that we ever get inside of. We see the effect that Andy has had on him, and in a way we feel that too. The chemistry between Robbins and Freeman was fantastic. As the film explores both of the characters, we get to see the friendship that they have created for each other, and it is heartwarming. The supporting cast also has done a great job in this film, especially Bob Gunton, James Whitmore and Bill Sadler.

The Shawshank Redemption is an amazing piece of cinema, and Darabont has created something that has inspired so many people to not give up on themselves and believe in hope. If a film has the ability to touch so many people, then it is definitely something very special.

I enjoyed this the first time I saw it. But then again I was only an easily impressionable 14-year-old, craving for new emotion. Recently, more than 10 years later, I revisited it, and barely managed to finish it. Bluntly, it's as plain and trite as it gets. In fact, I believe Frank deliberately wanted it that way, so that it would increase its appeal to the casual movie goers. In general, I have no problem with a simple, feel-good movie that does not take itself too seriously and is not looking to change its audience in a profound way. However, this does and it seems it is succeeding unfortunately....

We have a story about hope and its redemptive qualities, portrayed by an innocent man that is sent to prison(Tim's character). It's told through the eyes of his closest prison friend(Morgan's character). The narrative framing and flow are rigid, there is no rhythm, no ebb and flow, no metaphors, no irony, just constant relentless narration - extreme simplicity. It's stripped to the point that you can only remember the generic message. Dangerous stuff. Some people carry it around and "apply" it diligently. The others, only observe the snowball effect.

I hope there are more intelligent endeavors out there. I hope everyone sees them and appreciates them. I hope...

The Shawshank Redemption is not just one of the best films of the nineties but also one of the most loved and celebrated films of all time. The story, based on a Stephen King novella, is about the friendship between two men who bond over a number of years while locked up in prison. The film's most touching aspect, and the one that one would find fulfilling about the film, is the way in which it portrays the longing and pain of the fight for freedom and even redemption. But The Shawshank Redemption is also about human connections and human warmth, both feelings that would not be identified in the confined setting of a prison, but still exist because, as the story implies, it is necessary for survival. But what also makes this film deeply satisfying is the wonderful and tasteful direction with which Darabont brings the story to the big screen and a beautiful and meticulous cinematography that feels faithful to the emotions the film carries across. Robbins and Morgan head a great cast with great performances that complete the picture of an excellent touching and poignant film.

The Shawshank Redemption (1994)

The reality and the awful truth of "The Shawshank Redemption," created in 1994, rings home for most viewers. It is a movie in which you want the innocent man to go free and for the old man to live his dreams, outside of prison. Director Frank Darabont does an excellent job playing to the emotions of his viewers, as well as creating an engaging script with an even more impressive cast.

At the beginning of the film, we see Andy Dufresne, played by Tim Robbins, in a trial being convicted of murdering his wife and her lover. This very opening scene grabs a viewer right away. It is as though Andy's stoic and reserved facial expressions make his statements of innocence even more believable. As a viewer, I wanted to see Andy go free. I wanted to see him be innocent.  Nonetheless, he is sent to Shawshank prison, notorious for long and brutal sentences. Within this prison, we meet Red, played by Morgan Freeman, who has already been there for 20 years, convicted of murder as well. Red is the man that is friends with anyone and can get anything you could want outside the prison walls. He is able to play to the viewer's emotions and really show that the relationships that he forms are genuine. 

The warden and Officer Hadley, head of the guards, are out to make sure that everyone's lives in Shawshank Prison are living hell. Andy was a great friend with Red, but he also made sure to be on the good side of the warden and Officer Hadley. This was worked in well with the rest of the plot. As time went on, Andy would begin to take care of these two men's money problems. He became the man that did the books for the prison, and in this way, the viewer is convinced of the relationships that are being formed. The warden treats him extra special, by letting him be in the offices and build a library for the prison, and Officer Hadley beats up any men that even try to come at Andy, in any kind of physical attack. These two men do a wonderful job of creating a menacing role that would scare the viewer into the next lifetime when it comes to being at a prison, but the "soft" side can also be seen. The viewer hopes that these two men will actually turn out to be good guys in the end, because of all of the help that they are giving to Andy. Andy knew how to play the game the correct way, though; keep your friends close and your enemies closer. 

The engaging script keeps the viewer hooked throughout the entire movie. This movie spans over 20 years, and the viewer never loses interest. Not only that, but the script was full of unique, yet easy language to follow along with. This movie is not for the young crowd, but it is a good educational tool that can be used to truly convey what happened in some of the prisons in the early-mid 1900s. That is something that not all movies can really do. This is a must see movie, no matter what.

Yes, after years of putting it off, I have finally sat down and watched The Shawshank Redemption.

This film tells the story of Andy Dufresne, a convicted but innocent felon who was accused of murdering his wife and her lover. Dufresne is sentenced to life in Shawshank prison. There, he befriends a Morgan Freeman's character Red. The two of them become inspirable and they become each other's support as they both serve harsh time.

The audience watches as Dufresne makes his special mark on Shawshank prison. Whether it was because he helped expand the range of books in the library, he helped a young misunderstood boy achieve his high school diploma, or he helped most of the guards as well as the warden file their taxes just in time for tax season, Dufresne seemed to have made Shawshank a little less like a prison and a little more like a center for rehabilitation.

As 19 years came up, Dufresne discovered who had actually killed his wife and her lover. Dufresne is determined to become a free man, one way or another, even if the warden should attempt to gets in his way.

This film is a piece of art and I encourage everyone to experience if just as I have. This film is about friendship, loyalty, strength, truthfulness, and fighting for what's right, even when you seem outnumbered.

Frank Darabont's less-than-enthralling direction and screenplay can be summed up as such: a bland, pseudo-intellectual, and quite lazily told story that follows a set of totally unsympthetic characters. To clarify, it is not a bad film per se, but the popular appeal evades me. The puported depth of the film could be explained by conjuring images of you diving into a murky lake expecting the water to be deep enough to substantiate the dive, though awkwardly enough the water is shallow and it would appear you're headed to the emergency room.  
Blandness just seems to envelope the film and its unsympthetic cast of characters. The storytelling is far from bad, intially at least, but it just seems to contently lull in its own sauntering pace. But the blandness doesn't seem solely perpetuated by the storyline, rather it seems the characters ensure the film's humdrum script will remain as such for the duration. Tim Robbins portrayal of Andy Dusfrane is honestly just boring and uneventful, I'm not demanding spectacle but there's just nothing about this character that draws me in. His innoncence is obvious, his predicament is unfortunate, yet nothing about Andy brings about any sympathetic feelings, and most concerningly his abuse at the hands of the other inmates just comes across as matter of fact. The inability of his tragedy to draw any real raw emotional response from me isn't isolated to his performance. Bob Gunton's portrayal of the warden was bland as well. This is a role, unlike Andy Dusfrane, that I can saw would easily evoke some raw emotional response from me. But problematically Bob Gunton failed to achieve this, the Warden's inherently evil actions and even his (*spoiler alert*) inevitable suicide drew nothing. The lack of reaction is simple in its roots and I don't want to fall into repition here but its just a bland portrayal. 
Morgan Freeman is "on the fence" for me so to speak. I didn't find his portrayal or narration overly bland like many of his fellow castmembers. However I can't say it was overly inspiring or emotional evoking. To be honest his final meeting with the board kind of pissed me off. I'll be honest this is going to sound childish and maybe I'm missing something here (my first watch through was at 3am so I was tired as it was), but am I supposed to take this seriously? All of a sudden he turns around from affirming rehabilitation to questioning rehabilition as a whole? Am I supposed to feel sympathy? Your character is a murderer, so I don't feel sorry that you've spent the past 40 years of your life in prison. "To tell you the truth I don't give a shit," and after that bombshell the board decides to release you? Because that makes a load of sense, rather than when he was affirming it years in the past there's a sudden change of heart? I won't say what Morgan said in this little speech of his wasn't meaningful, it was kind of of powerful in its own right, but I can't help but feel like this is nothing less than lazy storytelling to have the board release him on that. Its satisfying, but it just comes across as an easy way of the storyline so he can be reunited with Dusfrane outside of prison. To be honest the logic of the board accepting this explanation and affirming his release, might as well have been accompanied by a slow clap from all of the board members. It has that melodramatic quality and frankly that quality only affirms the laziness of the storytelling here.
The blandness of the film overwhelms me and I get more intellectual enthrallment from watching Segei Eisenstein's 1925 silent film Battleship Potemkin than I do from this. And that's Soviet propoganda mind you.

The Shawshank Redemption stands as one of the greatest films I've ever seen in my life, with an interesting story and plot structure, memorable and likeable characters, and a fantastically shot setting.

Based on the Stephen King short story "Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption", the movie follows Andy Dufrane's (Tim Robbins) time spent in Shawshank prison for murdering his wife and her lover. Throughout the movie he maintains his innocence. During his time in Shawshank, which is run by an extremely religious though morally corrupt warden who makes his life miserable, he befriends another prisoner named Red (Morgan Freeman) who brings him things for a price.

A major theme throughout the film is the absense of freedom in a supposedly free world and the freedom in the world of the prison. It's an interesting idea that's explored through both the characters of Brooks and Red. The story is interesting and keeps you interested in all the characters...except for Dufrane, who is kinda a boring protagonist really. Robbins just plays him as this detached character who just happens to have a skill that helps him survive the life of a prisoner. More interesting, luckily, is the supporting cast. Freeman is amazing as usual in the role of Red, and the actor playing the Warden excells in conveying a quietly menacing, unlikable character. The cinematography is absolutely exsquisite, giving the prison a grim and dank environment.

This is definitely a must see for cinemaphiles and Stephen King fans alike. This is not only in my opinion the greatest adaptation of a Stephen King short story, but just an amazing film in its own right. If you haven't seen it right, see it as soon as possible. (Real Rating: 99%)

The Shawshank Redemption:
How Dialog Was Converted From Film to Book


I've seen The Shawshank Redemption several times before and it has interested me into seeing if the film is similar to the book. After reading the book I've decided that The Shawshank Redemption successfully and accurately used dialog and conversation in the book to turn it into an accurate film adaptation.

At the beginning of the film, Morgan Freeman's character, Red, begins to narrate as he does in the book. Most film adaptations of books change dialog and actiom to add more of an appeal but, Frank Darabont stuck as closely to the book as possible when directing this film.

There isn't much conversation in The Shawshank Redemption, it is mostly narration, but, when there is conversation it is the same in both the film and book. One of my the best parts of the story is when Red gives gives a lesson about hope. I had to look back a few times but Freeman had given the speech word for word. The fact that this is a turning point in the story makes it very important that it is included word for word in the film.

The Shawshank Redemption is one of my all time favorite movies and I enjoyed having the opportunity to write a paper about it. All of the reviews I had read have the same opinions as i do. That the film and the book are extremely similar and that adds to its popularity. One thing that I can point out is that Andy Dufresne, in the book, is described as a tall lanky man with gold glasses. in the film, Tim Robbins is not very lanky more of a husky type build. I'm not saying he was a bad choice to play Andy Dufresne, I just think that thats one thing that the film had a little leeway with handling.

Before we can critically assess The Shawshank Redemption, we first have to deal with The Shawshank Reputation. In addition to its Oscar nominations and huge critical acclaim, the film has topped the IMDb Top 250 for years and shows no signs of dropping off any time soon. Any attempt to criticise it could come across as churlish or contrarian, the work of someone attempting to be above what is popular for their own self-righteous sake. Fortunately, there is little need to criticise - for Shawshank really is as great as people make it out to be.

It's easy to forget how much of a slow-burning success Shawshank was. Despite favourable reviews and its many nominations, the film barely broke even on first release. It was only with the VHS release that word began to spread like wildfire, so that by the turn of the century it had garnered a reputation as a modern American great. In an age where films are dead in the water if they don't perform on opening weekend, it is hard to imagine a situation in which another Shawshank could emerge (although Slumdog Millionaire is a reasonable candidate).

It's equally easy to forget how brutal the film is, particularly in its first 20 minutes. Shawshank's reputation as a popular favourite might lead the uninitiated to thinking that it's an uplifting, feel-good film - and it is true that these later moments are the ones which have most entered into popular consciousness. But any film about hope needs a source of despair to provide conflict, and Shawshank has more than enough violence and emotional trauma to justify its 15 certificate. As Mark Kermode famously remarked, there's a whole lot of Shawshank before the Redemption.

Even without its reputation, Shawshank is one of the best adaptations of Stephen King's work. Indeed, among King's dramatic stories, it is outshone only by its successor The Green Mile. Frank Darabont has a greater understanding of King than almost any other filmmaker: he gets the tone spot on and recreates the period setting brilliantly with the help of Roger Deakins' cinematography. Despite the much-parodied narration that punctuates the film, the drama unfolds naturally and believably throughout, with the characters always being at the forefront and naked exposition being kept to a bare minimum.

Shawshank is a good example of how adaptation works - or more specifically, how changes made to the original story in translation often benefit the finished product. The best example of this is the character of Red, who in the original novel is a red-headed Irishman. This is referred to jokingly by Morgan Freeman in one of his first conversations with Tim Robbins; when Andy asks why people call him Red, Red responds: "Maybe it's because I'm Irish.".

On top of Freeman's obvious ability, the casting decision makes sense because it adds an extra layer of meaning to the character. Red is one of the few black characters we come across; while he applies himself in different ways, he is as much of an outsider as Andy DuFresne. This is borne out by his remarks about institutionalisation, which are laughed off by his fellow inmates. Red may be well-connected when it comes to smuggling things in, but otherwise he is just as lonely as Andy.

Shawshank approaches the theme of institutionalisation with great grace and dexterity. Because the story takes place over three decades, the temptation would be to canter through the plot points and cut straight to Andy's escape - you could even stage the entire story in flashback. Instead, Darabont allows the film to unfold at a gentle, gradual pace, reflecting the mind-set of the characters. They don't realise how trapped they are until it's too late, just as we don't realise that two-and-a-half hours has passed until the credits have begun to roll.

The characters reflect the different extents and effects of institutionalisation. Brooks has built his entire identity around his books and role in the prison; he is so afraid of this being taken away that he attempts to kill William Sadler's character so he can stay inside. Red is aware of how trapped he is, and shares Brooks' fears, being unsure that he could get things for Andy on the outside. But at the same time, he refuses to let himself be vulnerable, trying to play the system and constantly getting turned down for parole. Andy allows himself to be vulnerable and endures all the pain that it brings him, sustained by the knowledge of his innocence and the hope that he will escape.

Shawshank is perhaps the most powerful depiction of hope in all of cinema. The original short story, Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption, was subtitled 'Hope Springs Eternal'. The film returns to hope and the celebration of the human spirit like a leitmotif, and succeeds because it retains Andy's humanity in all its many shades. While he is very different to the other prisoners, he is never presented as a saint or goody-goody, smiling gormlessly in the face of maddening torment. This makes his endurance all the more powerful: we recognise our faults in his moments of weakness, and aspire to his inner moral strength.

The film has attracted many Christian interpretations - in fact, in my review of John Carpenter's The Thing, I called it "a poster child for Christianity". It's not hard to see why, considering its celebration of inner strength and devotion, and its overall arc of good triumph over evil against the greatest odds. While Andy has been called a Christ figure, he's just as close to the character of Daniel in the Old Testament: he finds himself in a strange land against his will, and in order to survive he applies his natural talents to the service of his temporal masters. Through his labours the people around him benefit and the system is eventually changed for the better - albeit through pain, suffering and several deaths.

An equally intriguing interpretation comes from Mark Kermode, who authored a BFI Modern Classic on the film in 2003. In a video discussing cinematic depictions of Richard Nixon, Kermode made the argument that Warden Norton (played brilliantly by Bob Gunton) is an allegory for Nixon, with Andy's prison term matching Nixon's political career. Norton begins reaching out for friendship (Nixon seeking to be elected), then becomes the corrupt leader (beginning in the year that Kennedy was shot), and finally descends into paranoia and disgrace, culminating in a more literal suicide than Nixon offered us.

Whether you believe these interpretations or not, Shawshank is a terrific piece of dramatic film-making which soars on the strengths of its main performers. Tim Robbins perfectly captures Andy's distant, ethereal quality while retaining his wry and infectious sense of humour. Morgan Freeman's performance may well be responsible for his subsequent type-casting, but he matches Robbins beat for beat, offsetting hope with world-weariness and guilt. There's also great support from two actors who would subsequently work with Darabont again - William Sadler (who appears in The Green Mile) and James Whitmore (The Majestic).

The only fly in the ointment with Shawshank is its ending. The film is about hope as a value in and of itself, emphasising the importance of having it even if it is not rewarded. Red's transition to embracing hope is far more important than his reunion with Andy, and this reunion shifts the film's message from celebrating hope to justifying the characters' pain on the basis of a happy ending. It's also clear that this ending was put together at the last minute, with subtle shifts in the cinematography and a far more rushed pacing to it.

The Shawshank Redemption may not be entirely worthy of its number one ranking on IMDb, but it remains a really terrific piece of drama let down only by its final scene. In every other aspect it's a masterpiece, as a character piece, a treatise on hope and a beautifully paced and mounted Stephen King adaptation. It remains a must-see for all film fans of penchant or persuasion, earning its status as a modern classic and securing a warm place in our hearts.

I can understand how some people can feel that 'The Shawshank Redemption' feels underwhelming or bland, compared to other highly acclaimed movies. I guess having that notion that all classic films have to be complex, with a bunch of overarching themes can influence one's perceptions of what is supposed to be a quality film. I have learned that every director has a vision with its own distinctiveness that differs from other directors. Whether its small or large in its scope, sometimes that is not the point. Some directors want to prove something to make a point, while some just want to just make a story that's basically good, without the need to be over-politically or socially conscious to the point where it becomes pretentious.

And 'Shawshank' is basically that. A good simple story about one's will to hold on to hope despite how heavy the circumstances. Sure, some might not view it as realistic for a story about prison life, but applying to the concept of life in general is what fits and not if it rings true to how life in prison really is. It's a more of a 'life' film than a prison film. When one feels like they are in their own type of 'prison,' sometimes just having a friend to bring you a little freedom is all you need to feel free again, and that is a comforting message in all its beautiful simplicity.

With its 'floating on a cloud' atmosphere, it really has a soothing, calm, and tranquil atmosphere, despite the setting being a prison. This tone is what separates 'Shawshank' from other films and becomes its own distinct world and with that the film comes off feeling more hopeful than dark at times, and I think that's more than I can ask for from this great movie, at the end of the day.

This is my favorite movie based on a Stephen King novel after "The Green Mile." It has such a wide range of emotions in it, which I love. You feel "sad," "angry," "happy," but you always have hope. You have hope because of how Andy Deufrene becomes everybody's favorite in the prison. You feel angry because of the evil warden, and you hate him so much. The sisters also made you angry. 

But you feel a lot of warmth in this film, because of scenes like the one where Andy Deufrene is standing out in the rain. So amazing, and everything works out the way you want it to in this film. 

The whole idea of how you become dependent on the prison after a while is shown in such a great way, and I felt like I got a good impression as to how life in prison is like. I had such a fascination with this film for reasons like that. It is so awesome. 

The acting is also amazing. The best scene is when Red gets sent in, and they ask him do you feel rehabilitated, and he just asks what does that mean. it was such awesome scene, and Morgan Freeman delivered his usual amazing acting in that scene. I kept thinking "Yeah!" when he was talking to that guy. 

One movie that I would compare this to is Clint Eastwood's "Escape From Alcatraz." It had similar elements such as dealing with the rapist, a warden that you hate, dumping all of the rocks you dug out the night before, when you were trying to escape. It also had the same library that Shawshank had. However the big difference between the two is that "Escape from Alcatraz" is more of an exciting bad ass thriller, while Shawshank is more of an epic drama. Shawshank is still the greatest prison film of all time, and one of the greatest classics just in general. 

This film is on a list of movies that I will show my kids in about 20 years or so. This will always be great, and it will never die.

Una obra maestra, dirigida por Frank Darabont adaptando a la perfección el guión basado en un cuento corto de Stephen King. La trama se desarrolla practicamente idéntica al cuento original, pero la visión de Darabont fué clave para el impacto fílmico ya que fué su decisión la de usar a Morgan Freeman en el papel de "Red", y que sin duda, sin Freeman, la cinta nunca hubiera sido lo mismo. Ciertamente Tim Robbins desarrolla bien a su personaje, pero es la presencia de Morgan Freeman la que define el nivel de la producción. Pero sin duda, el resto del elenco son bien elegidos y cada uno aporta su grano de arena para consolidar esta gran película. El ritmo del filme es perfecto donde usted en dos horas y resto realmente llega a sentir el paso de 20 años dentro de la trama. La primera vez que la ven, te sorprende, pero inclusive, cuando la vuelves a ver, aunque ya sepas elementos clave de la trama, igualmente la vuelves a disfrutar, apreciando las impecables actuaciones y las memorables escenas. Si quisiera cambiar algo, creo que sería algo mínimo del inicio de la cinta, donde arrancan con "Andy", el personaje de Robbins que es el principal, y hasta luego de unos minutos entran con "Red", el personaje de Freeman. Como Freeman es el narrador de toda la película, creo que hubiera sido mejor, arrancar con él, y que Robbins entre en la trama, tal y como lo hacen al llegar a la prisión y presentar los minutos iniciales como un flashback. No es nada que vaya a cambiar la película, simplemente es algo que pienso cada vez que la veo. Altamente recomendada.

This marks the third film Robbins has appeared in that merits my All-Time Top 100 Movies list!  The other two pictures being by Robert Altman:  The Player, and Short Cuts.  
     Given the critical success of this Darabont then made another prison film, also based on a Stephen King short story, called The Green Mile. At Shawshank Andy befriends a fellow inmate, Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman) Red was a contraband smuggler.
